thread.title: Rand stronger despite local trade numbers, US data | Markets
thread.title_full: Rand stronger despite local trade numbers, US data | Markets | BDlive

author: Maarten Mittner
title: Rand stronger despite local trade numbers, US data | Markets
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK THE rand was firmer on Wednesday afternoon as the market shrugged off another bout of negative local trade figures and better than expected ADP employment data from the US.
The rand strengthened beyond the crucial resistance level of R13.82/$ to R13.7960 in intraday trade, before weakening slightly again.
At 3.25pm the rand was at R13.8463/$ from an overnight close of R13.9761/$.
Against the euro, the rand was at R15.4887 from R15.7322 previously and was at R21.0280 against the pound from a previous close of R21.1842.
The euro was at $1.1186 from $1.1250.
The exceptionally oversold position on the rand created fertile ground for a short-term value improvement in the local unit and a move back to R13.82/$ represented a realistic near-term target, Momentum SP Reid said in a note.
The trade deficit deteriorated further to R9.95bn in August from a revised deficit of R1.11bn (previously a deficit of R397m) in July.
This was theoretically negative for the rand, as it requires increased deficit funding. However, the cumulative trade deficit for the first nine months of the year came in at R36.27bn, compared with the R69.94bn for the same period last year, and so put a brake on rand losses.
The ADP employment report in the US for September showed private payroll growth of 200,000 on the month, slightly above consensus expectations (190,000) and broadly in line with recent trends.
The data could be viewed as supportive of a US rate hike this year, which would have a negative effect on emerging markets.
